title: Why is it necessary that singers lip-sync? - Quora

response.answer_text: My answer is complicated but very real and directed towards those people who know nothing about the intricacies of modern musical performances. I want to make it perfectly clear that any use of an artist’s name is only meant to give an example of the type of performance and DOES NOT imply that they lip sync or don’t. The first factor is what type of performance? Is the artist’s act also predominantly dance as in the case of Jennifer Lopez, Janet Jackson, Brittany Spears and other modern pop artists? If so, in a live show environment, there is a good chance that they are singing live along with prerecorded track. The artist’s mic is usually hot at certain times during the performance so they can sing if they choose and talk to the audience. For anyone who thinks lip sync is a rip off and phony, try this at home. Do 50 jumping jacks. Now run around your house or apartment building 5 times. Now do it five more times while singing Happy Birthday out loud. Hard to sing. Hard to catch your breath. Sound like crap don’t you? You’ve heard the obnoxious sound it makes when people blow in a microphone? All of that is why it’s done.In the case of TV performance, especially award shows such as the Academy Awards, Rockin’ New Year’s Eve or Superbowl half time show, everything is scripted to the second. In TV, time is BIG money. It is crucial for the performing artist to adhere strictly to the time schedule even five seconds of inconsistency can cause problems. Often it is written into the contract that they will sync for their TV performance so that show producers can count on the scripting and advertisement air times.I hope that helps. I’ve never met an artist who didn’t want to sing for their audience but many professionals understand the reality and technical challenges of today’s performances. Every artist I’ve ever worked with always wanted to give their audiences the best they could deliver.

It’s a technical challenge to pull off a live show with live vocal performances. There are times when the environment won’t cooperate. It’s too noisy for the performer to hear themselves above the rest of the band, the crowd is cheering too loud, the wind is creating loud blowing noises in the microphone, etc. As advanced as wireless mics have become over the years, there are times when holding a big hunk of metal and plastic in your hand isn’t practical. The little tiny ‘lavalier’ or ‘tie-clip’ mics also capture rubbing noises, as the fabric of a costume moves across a performer’s skin. Most of the time, singers who simply stand in one spot aren’t visually exciting. This is why the performer is also dancing elaborate choreography. However, singing is tough enough without running out of breath running and jumping all over the stage. TV borrowed a trick from the film industry, and encouraged the performers to pantomime “singing” to pre-recorded tracks. Recording audio in a studio, an enviromnent designed for the purpose of capturing sound, allows the director and technical staff to focus on the visual aspects: lighting, camera lenses, camera movement and placement, and so on. Most of the time it works… however, Ms. Carey’s recent performance is an example of when things go wrong.
